qas.question: What does the US national council for Young Isreal represent?
What is involvement with non-orthodox Jews known as?
What is a core beliefe that was recognized as important by orthodox Jews?
what is it important for both men and women orthodox jews to be able to do?

plausible_answers.text: U.S. National Council for Young Israel

qas.question: What council is considered to be anti-Zionist?
What are affiliates of the State of Israel typically not?
Who avoids any practices with non-Orthodox Jews?
What is not considered to be a core belief of Zionists?
Who do the Jews consider to be more worthy of a higher education?

context: <a0_0>Modern Orthodoxy<a0_0/>, as a stream of Orthodox Judaism represented by institutions such as the <b4_0>U.S. National Council for Young Israel<b4_0/>, is pro-Zionist and thus places a high national, as well as religious, significance on the State of Israel, and its affiliates are, typically, <b5_0><b6_0>Zionist<b6_0/> in orientation<b5_0/>. It also practices involvement with non-Orthodox Jews that extends beyond <a1_0>"outreach (Kiruv)"<a1_0/> to continued institutional relations and cooperation; see further under Torah Umadda. Other "core beliefs" are a recognition of the value and importance of <a2_0><b7_0>secular studies<b7_0/><a2_0/>, a commitment to equality of education for both <b8_0>men<b8_0/> and women, and a full acceptance of the importance of being able to financially <a3_0>support oneself<a3_0/> and one's family.
